content.html: @tom Back when Twitter first created lists, I had a list of people called Bob. I think it was one of the few things I enjoyed on Twitter.

content.html: (I decided that although this is Twitter-related, I want to share it, because this was a good memory of my time there, and I want to keep those alive, as much as I want to thing it is now to die)

content.html:
@tom fun!

When I started at Twitter (UK) we had 5 Toms (out of 100 people at the time, I was UK employee 100). They ended up having their own spot on the feature wall at reception when we moved to the bespoke office. #TooManyToms

This makes a lot of sense. I've seen sports-related posts with 40 tags. Those should be hidden at the bottom and expandable.

content.html:
@tchambers potentially, you'd still need at least one of the radios to be connected to traditional internet. And you immediately run into a recentralization problem, where you have to trust the person running the Mastodon bridge.

The ideal situation (and I'm not sure if C2S is at a point yet where this would work), is you being able to sign an activity, send that activity over meshtastic and then any number of people could run delivery radios that take your signed activity and give it to your server. Which would be pretty cool
content.text:
@tchambers potentially, you'd still need at least one of the radios to be connected to traditional internet. And you immediately run into a recentralization problem, where you have to trust the person running the Mastodon bridge.

The ideal situation (and I'm not sure if C2S is at a point yet where this would work), is you being able to sign an activity, send that activity over meshtastic and then any number of people could run delivery radios that take your signed activity and give it to your server. Which would be pretty cool
